narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A general overview of planning and optimization topics, and detailed insights into how the various methods work and where they might fall short.

The main knowledge areas that I developed in this course were implementing classic planning algorithms, evaluating matrix derivatives and framing optimization problems. I also gained more insights into how to approach problems that sit at the intersection of planning and optimization. For example, how should a notion of cost be incorporated into a continuous-space planner, so that the plan is optimal with respect to that cost?
I have learned discrete and continuous motion planning algorithms and optimization methods

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course covers a lot of topics in applied planning and optimization, with plenty of detailed inner workings on a lot of the topics. Depending on one's background and interest in these topics, the material on how the methods work, some math derivations, and so on may be too detailed. But these are still good to know (although their application could be further emphasized at times, maybe if that is the intention of the course?) and the instructor still tries to emphasize the reasons why the underlying math is important to understand. The biggest strength of the course in my opinion is the broader understanding of the planning and optimization fields that students can take away, and the notes are a great resource to look at when working with these methods in the future too.

Professor Rakita is a good lecturer, and he is a very nice person, but the class is not very well organized. We had two assignments before spring break, and got around 6 assignments and the final projects in the last two weeks of classes.

One of the main strengths of the course is the quality of the materials - the class notes are well-structured for review. I found many of the interactive visualizations to be particularly helpful in building intuition around the iterative optimization methods discussed in the final units of the course. The lectures were also engaging and touched on 
There weren't any glaring weaknesses, though I think that more "real-world" and "research-type" examples could be introduced in the lectures around (for example) regularization or trust-region methods.

Strength: Provided a perfect lecture note that is well-written and structured. 
Weakness: None

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course is useful for anyone interested in planning and optimization, ideally in robotics but other fields too. The instructor presents enough detail for those who wish to dive deep into the topics, but the course also covers broad breadth of topics for students interested in the general methods, when they can be applied and what their strengths/weaknesses are. Overall, I highly recommend this course!
Yes, if he is interested in optimization, and I think the course structure will improve next time.

This course is a great introduction to both analytical and numerical methods for optimization, and also for classic planning. I found the optimization half of the course to be more challenging, but also more rewarding. If you are interested in either area, this course gives a strong theoretical grounding, but also the opportunity for hands-on application of the concepts discussed in lecture in the problem sets and programming assignments.
I strongly recommend this course if you are interested in motion planning and optimization. The process of solving assignments is highly rewarding and highly useful for future research
